resources.string: Your device includes support for Project Treble. VNDK %1$s is also bundled alongside it.
Your device includes support for the legacy version of Project Treble. VNDK %1$s is also bundled alongside it.
Your device does not support Project Treble.

Project Treble separates the Android OS and the hardware abstraction layer through an HIDL interface. This enables the upgrading the Android OS without rebuilding the hardware-specific code. Devices that support Project Treble can then install system images that are based on newer versions of Android and experience new features that come with it.
Your device includes support for Seamless System Updates and is detected to have an A/B system partition.

Your device includes support for the new Seamless System Updates and is detected to have a virtual A/B system partition. Virtual A/B partitions can be freely resized accordingly depending on the amount of space needed.

Your device can install system updates in the background resulting to minimal user interruption. Installing updates is also less risky as the device can reboot back into the old partition and remain usable once something goes wrong with an update.
Your device does not support Seamless System Updates and is detected to have an A-only system partition.

Your device only uses one partition for the system, resulting to the device being temporarily unusable while an update is taking place. Failed updates can also render the device unusable until a fix is applied.
Your device uses a CPU with %1$s architecture.
Your device uses a CPU with an unknown architecture.
Your device includes support for system-as-root.
Your device does not support system-as-root.
There was an error reading the mounted file systems on your device.
Easier, faster, less costly Android OS updates

Project Treble separates the vendor implementation (device-specific, lower-level software written by silicon manufacturers) from the Android OS framework via a new vendor interface. In Android 7.x and earlier, no formal vendor interface exists so device makers must update large portions of the Android code to move a device to a newer version of Android.

With Treble, a new stable vendor interface provides access to the hardware-specific parts of Android, enabling device makers to deliver new Android releases simply by updating the Android OS framework—without any additional work required from the silicon manufacturers.
Show your love and support for the app by donating. Donations help us maintain quality apps like this and develop more in the future.

"v3.0.1 – 04/27/2020 – [added] list of contributors to the app, huge thanks to them! – [added] explainer for Project Treble is now back – [added] support for checking 64-bit CPU but 32-bit OS – [added] updated app translations – [fixed] bug causing crashes when detecting system-as-root status – [fixed] bug causing text to be clipped on the edges
v3.0.0 – 04/20/2020 – updated design – added support for identifying Virtual A/B partitions – added support for checking System-as-root and CPU Architecture – general improvements and bug fixes"
